messages.text: <https://forums.rockylinux.org/t/community-update-december-2020/1157>

attachments.title: Community Update - December 2020
attachments.text: Community Update - December 2020 Summary Our teams are working to coordinate the many individuals and organizations that have offered to help advance The Rocky Linux Foundation, Inc. (Rocky Linux). The core team is working to lay the infrastructure that will support the legal entity and the engineering efforts required to deliver and support an initial release. Updates regarding project news, release dates, and more will be announced on our forums, website, and other social media platforms. Tim...
attachments.fallback: Rocky Linux Discourse: Community Update - December 2020

messages.text: > We have outgrown Slack due to the size of the community and required feature sets, and will therefore be migrating to Mattermost 111. This open source platform has a number of features we’ll be taking advantage of, including: an IRC bridge, multi-factor authentication, advanced logging / auditing / security capabilities, and fidelity in channel and access permissions.

elements.text: We have outgrown Slack due to the size of the community and required feature sets, and will therefore be migrating to Mattermost 111. This open source platform has a number of features we’ll be taking advantage of, including: an IRC bridge, multi-factor authentication, advanced logging / auditing / security capabilities, and fidelity in channel and access permissions.

messages.text: <@UDB26738Q>, <@U67BJLYCS> and I were talking about the next steps for Spack integration, and I thought it might be time to actually sit down and write out the next step of JLLWrappers functionality

elements.text: and I were talking about the next steps for Spack integration, and I thought it might be time to actually sit down and write out the next step of JLLWrappers functionality

messages.text: Here’s what I’m thinking we want to do: We want to have JLLWrappers generate bindings that are instrumented in almost every conceivable way with `Preferences.jl`, such that the user can override all sorts of things.  The first thing I was thinking it would be useful to support overriding is the filename of Library Products

elements.text: Here’s what I’m thinking we want to do: We want to have JLLWrappers generate bindings that are instrumented in almost every conceivable way with
Preferences.jl
, such that the user can override all sorts of things.  The first thing I was thinking it would be useful to support overriding is the filename of Library Products

messages.text: e.g. overriding `product_soname` here:

elements.text: e.g. overriding
product_soname
here:

messages.text: <https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/JLLWrappers.jl/blob/master/src/products/library_generators.jl#L21>

I think this is important for two reasons:

* I’d like to use it to support “just load my system library”.  We can even use this mode by default for people who build Julia with `USE_SYSTEM_XXX=1`.
* It’s necessary for spack, but we don’t want to blindly load anything in Spack-land, we want to load the exact version that Spack gives us.

elements.text:
I think this is important for two reasons:

* I’d like to use it to support “just load my system library”.  We can even use this mode by default for people who build Julia with
USE_SYSTEM_XXX=1

.
* It’s necessary for spack, but we don’t want to blindly load anything in Spack-land, we want to load the exact version that Spack gives us.

Is there such a thing as a parametric job scheduler in HPC where you can say stuff like: If i get x nodes with Y RAM i will need f(x,y) time to complete?
Scheduling either task a with x1 nodes and y1 ram exclusive-or task b with x2 nodes and y2 ram xor ... would also work.

messages.text:
I have some function that fills matrix entries over 3 for loops, something like
```function foo(a::Matrix)
    fill!(a,0.0)
    for k in 1:kstop
        some_variable = huge_amount_of_work(k)
        for i in 1:istop
            for j in 1:jstop
                a[i,j] += some_variable * little_bit_of_work(i,j)
            end
        end
    end
end```
could I use a SharedArray to iterate over k, such that `huge_amount_of_work` is distributed by `@distributed for k in 1:kstop` ?

elements.text: I have some function that fills matrix entries over 3 for loops, something like

function foo(a::Matrix)
    fill!(a,0.0)
    for k in 1:kstop
        some_variable = huge_amount_of_work(k)
        for i in 1:istop
            for j in 1:jstop
                a[i,j] += some_variable * little_bit_of_work(i,j)
            end
        end
    end
end
could I use a SharedArray to iterate over k, such that
huge_amount_of_work
is distributed by
@distributed for k in 1:kstop

I have a naive question, how do I `addprocs` via SSHManager on a remote EC2 machine? I have configured the machine to be able to use my private key to login directly, but the following doesn’t seem to work

```addprocs([("aws-comput-1", 1)]; exename="/home/ubuntu/.ion/bin/julia", dir="/home/ubuntu")```

messages.text: I wrapped PAPI back in the day and it worked but does need to be updated, not sure who owns it now.  I think there are other options that Valentine has suggested like LIKWD which IMO are better or largely eqv.  There is an ongoing effort to update PAPI as part of the exascale modernization project, and those changes look interesting (heterogeneous hardware support, cleaner design, etc.)

elements.text: I wrapped PAPI back in the day and it worked but does need to be updated, not sure who owns it now.  I think there are other options that Valentine has suggested like LIKWD which IMO are better or largely eqv.  There is an ongoing effort to update PAPI as part of the exascale modernization project, and those changes look interesting (heterogeneous hardware support, cleaner design, etc.)

messages.text: Well the people I'm working with right now are using PAPI in their regular workloads because (for them) it seems to have the lowest overhead when doing instruction counter based measuring. The question came up whether or not bindings to PAPI exist in julia, what the overhead would be, how the counters are influenced etc. We're particularly interested in checking whether or not the code is hitting hardware bottlenecks with expected GFLOPs or not, for which those kinds of profiling methods are much more suitable than e.g. backtracing profiling as is done in the Profile stdlib.

elements.text: Well the people I'm working with right now are using PAPI in their regular workloads because (for them) it seems to have the lowest overhead when doing instruction counter based measuring. The question came up whether or not bindings to PAPI exist in julia, what the overhead would be, how the counters are influenced etc. We're particularly interested in checking whether or not the code is hitting hardware bottlenecks with expected GFLOPs or not, for which those kinds of profiling methods are much more suitable than e.g. backtracing profiling as is done in the Profile stdlib.

messages.text: My gut tells me "if you follow the three steps of staying non-allocating, multi-threading where possible and throwing `@avx` on the hot parts, you'll probably be IO bound", but it's always nice to confirm that (and if it turns out that we're not, what do we have to change such that we are?)

elements.text: My gut tells me "if you follow the three steps of staying non-allocating, multi-threading where possible and throwing
@avx
on the hot parts, you'll probably be IO bound", but it's always nice to confirm that (and if it turns out that we're not, what do we have to change such that we are?)
